;

;Recently, Meng Hai, a martial arts instructor, martial arts actor, and an important member of the Hong Family Class, passed away. He died just a year after his unfortunate diagnosis of esophageal cancer. His death should draw everyone's attention to esophageal cancer.

;

;The main risk factors for esophageal cancer and gastric cancer among Chinese residents are: hot food, fried food, pickled food, heavy salt food, irregular meals and drinking and smoking, especially while smoking. Drinking alcohol; eating garlic, fresh vegetables, and drinking warm tea were protective factors.

;

;Esophageal cancer is a common digestive tract tumor. Its typical symptoms are progressive dysphagia. First, there is a feeling of choking and foreign body when swallowing food, then it is difficult to swallow dry food, and finally, half of the food is swallowed. Fluids and even water cannot be swallowed. Esophageal cancer can also cause retrosternal pain. If it metastasizes or invades adjacent organs, the affected organs will feel uncomfortable and painful. It usually invades the larynx and causes hoarseness. Therefore, if the throat is uncomfortable, it may not necessarily mean that you talk too much, but it may also be an emergency signal from the body. If cancer invades the lower esophagus, it can involve the gastroesophageal junction, which may cause hematemesis or hematochezia; if it invades the trachea, it can cause dyspnea or hemoptysis.

;

;About 300,000 people die from esophageal cancer every year in the world. China is one of the areas with a high incidence of esophageal cancer in the world, with relatively high incidence and mortality rates. The incidence rate ranks sixth among all malignant tumors, and the mortality rate ranks fourth, with an average of about 150,000 deaths per year.

;

;There are many factors that cause esophageal cancer, including age, gender, occupation, race, region, living environment, eating habits, genes, inflammation and trauma, and trace elements. In terms of gender, there are more men than women, and the age of onset is mostly over 40 years old. However, it is worth noting that in recent years, there has been an increasing trend in those under 40 years of age.

;

;From a geographical perspective, the incidence rate of esophageal cancer in rural areas is higher than that in cities. But the essence of the region here is the level of economic development. Generally speaking, in relatively developed areas, lung cancer, colorectal cancer, breast cancer, thyroid cancer, and prostate cancer are more likely to occur, while in relatively economically backward areas, digestive tract tumors such as gastric cancer, esophageal cancer, and liver cancer are more likely to occur.

;

;From a purely geographical distribution perspective, China's esophageal cancer high-incidence areas are mainly concentrated near the Taihang Mountains: Henan, Hebei, Shanxi, Shandong, Anhui, and Jiangsu and northern Jiangsu regions. This kind of regional incidence is very common in cancer. For example, the high incidence areas of nasopharyngeal cancer are Guangdong, Guangxi, Fujian, Hunan and other southern regions.

;

;There is also a geographical distribution, which is actually genetic distribution. Other high-incidence areas of esophageal cancer are related to immigrants from the Central Plains, including Nanchong, Sichuan, Yanting, Sichuan, Shantou, Guangdong, and Fuzhou, Fujian. This is because certain groups of people carry susceptibility genes.

;

;The high-risk factors for esophageal cancer are the most common in daily life and can be summarized in four words: smoking, alcohol, scalding, and pickling.

;

;Epidemiological surveys have found that smoking is quite common among residents in some areas with a high incidence of esophageal cancer. In some areas, residents do not smoke, and esophageal cancer is rare. The incidence of esophageal cancer is high among Indian Muslims, Christians and Hindus who are fond of smoking ebony leaf tobacco and chewing musk leaves, while it is rare among Zoroastrians who do not have this hobby.

;

;Epidemiological surveys have also found that many patients with esophageal cancer have a history of heavy drinking. Scientists from the United Kingdom and Hong Kong, China, investigated the smoking and drinking status of esophageal cancer patients in Hong Kong. After detailed comparative analysis, they found that drinking alcohol may be more likely to cause esophageal cancer than smoking. Esophageal cancer in China is mainly squamous cell carcinoma. Smoking and heavy drinking are important factors causing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. For esophageal squamous cell carcinoma, the incidence of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma increases by 3-8 times in smokers and 7-50 times in drinkers.

;

;In areas with a high incidence of esophageal cancer in my country, many residents and esophageal cancer patients have the habit of eating hot food. Researchers measured the food temperature of residents in high-incidence areas and found that it could be as high as 70°C-80°C, with a maximum of 80°C-88°C. This is a very hot temperature. Hot water at 75°C can cause epithelial cell degeneration in mice, mucosal inflammation and cell nucleic acid metabolism. Therefore, local inflammation and thermal stimulation caused by long-term hot diet may be a contributing or inducing factor in the onset of esophageal cancer. In Japan, people who like to eat hot porridge and hot tea have a higher incidence rate. In addition to eating hot food, overeating, fast eating, and dry and hard food can also irritate the esophagus and cause cancer.

;

;Nitrite is also an important factor in causing esophageal cancer and gastric cancer. Long-term consumption of pickled foods and excessive nitrite intake can also lead to esophageal cancer. In areas with a high incidence of esophageal cancer, the nitrosamine content in food and drinking water is significantly higher than in other areas. More than sixty years ago, gastric cancer was the main cancer in Japan. After the popularization of refrigerators in the 1970s, people ate less pickled food, and the incidence of gastric cancer in Japan dropped significantly.

;

;However, although esophageal cancer is terrible, it can also be prevented. Avoid high-risk factors such as smoking and heavy drinking, eat less pickled foods, and eat less hot things. If the local drinking water quality is not good, you can add Install a water purifier. People who live in high-incidence areas, are over 45 years old, have a direct family history of esophageal cancer or digestive tract cancer, or have a history of other cancers or precancerous diseases of esophageal cancer should undergo esophageal cancer screening for early detection and early treatment.
